questions.text: A patient presented with fever, weight loss and night sweats. He had 2 previous episodes of hemoptysis. His radiograph showed a cavitary lesion in the right lung. Which of the following is the mechanism of cavitation in his lungs?

TB-related cavitation is not caused by antibody-mediated, IgE-mediated, or immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an autoimmune disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ulcerative colitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ulcerative colitis is an immune-mediated disorder but lacks a well-defined autoantigen, so it is not classified as an autoimmune disease. True autoimmune diseases (e.g., Grave’s disease, RA, SLE) involve a specific autoantigen and autoantibodies. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) includes Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, both driven by immune dysregulation rather than direct autoimmune mechanisms.
  • ➤ Ulcerative colitis is an immune-mediated disorder but lacks a well-defined autoantigen, so it is not classified as an autoimmune disease.
  • ➤ True autoimmune diseases (e.g., Grave’s disease, RA, SLE) involve a specific autoantigen and autoantibodies.
  • ➤ Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) includes Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, both driven by immune dysregulation rather than direct autoimmune mechanisms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with excessive bleeding following a minor injury. She has no personal or family history of bleeding disorders. Laboratory testing reveals a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) that does not correct after mixing her plasma with normal plasma. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acquired factor VIII inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acquired factor VIII inhibitor is characterized by spontaneous development of autoantibodies against factor VIII, leading to excessive bleeding. It presents with a prolonged aPTT that does NOT correct with a mixing study. Confirmed by the Bethesda assay, it is treated with immunosuppression (steroids, rituximab) and bypass agents for bleeding control.
  • ➤ Acquired factor VIII inhibitor is characterized by spontaneous development of autoantibodies against factor VIII, leading to excessive bleeding.
  • ➤ It presents with a prolonged aPTT that does NOT correct with a mixing study.
  • ➤ Confirmed by the Bethesda assay, it is treated with immunosuppression (steroids, rituximab) and bypass agents for bleeding control.

questions.text: A 15-year-old tall male with long limbs presents with multiple painless mucosal nodules on the lips and tongue, thickening of the corneal nerves, and a family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) in his father. Physical examination reveals a ganglioneuroma on the posterior tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: An elderly patient dies due to a cancer and his cells in the cancer affected area were examined. Ultra structurally, the most prominent features found are the loss of mitochondrial cristae and ruptured outer mitochondrial membrane. Which of the following best can be the pattern of cell death here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ferroptosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent form of regulated cell death characterized by mitochondrial cristae loss and lipid peroxidation. It is distinct from apoptosis, necrosis, and necroptosis. Key regulators include iron metabolism and glutathione peroxidase (GPX4).
  • ➤ Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent form of regulated cell death characterized by mitochondrial cristae loss and lipid peroxidation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with headaches, unsteady gait, and vomiting. Neurological examination reveals truncal ataxia. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows a midline mass in the posterior fossa compressing the fourth ventricle. Histological analysis of the tumor demonstrates small, blue, undifferentiated cells with a high mitotic index. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Medulloblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, arising in the midline cerebellum and often causing obstructive hydrocephalus. Histology shows small blue cells with high mitotic activity and Homer-Wright rosettes. It commonly spreads via the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and may cause drop metastases in the spinal cord.
  • ➤ Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, arising in the midline cerebellum and often causing obstructive hydrocephalus.

Laboratory tests show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and thyrotoxicosis with an increased serum concentration of free thyroxine (T4). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney? It is the most common subtype of malignant renal tumor Associated with loss of long arm of chromosome 3 Arises from distal convoluted tubule Cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat

questions.text: Which of the following cell within cell phenomenon is associated with cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Emperipolesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emperipolesis is a process in which one cell enters another without being degraded. It is seen in Rosai-Dorfman disease, leukemias, and some hematologic disorders. It differs from entosis (which leads to degradation) and efferocytosis (which clears apoptotic cells).

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about liquid biopsy?

options.label: A
options.text: Liquid biopsy primarily relies on the analysis of tissue samples obtained through surgical procedures.

options.label: B
options.text: It is mainly used for the diagnosis of infectious diseases and not for cancer detection.

options.label: C
options.text: Liquid biopsy involves the analysis of biomarkers, such as circulating tumor cells and cell-free DNA, in bodily fluids like blood or urine.

options.label: D
options.text: Liquid biopsy is only used to determine the exact stage of cancer but not for initial detection.

questions.correct_answer: C. Liquid biopsy involves the analysis of biomarkers, such as circulating tumor cells and cell-free DNA, in bodily fluids like blood or urine.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Liquid biopsy involves the analysis of biomarkers, such as circulating tumor cells and cell-free DNA, in bodily fluids like blood or urine.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liquid biopsy is a non-invasive technique that detects tumor biomarkers like CTCs and cfDNA in blood or urine. It is useful for early cancer detection, monitoring treatment response, and identifying resistance mutations. Unlike traditional biopsy, it does not require invasive procedures and can be repeated multiple times.
  • ➤ Liquid biopsy is a non-invasive technique that detects tumor biomarkers like CTCs and cfDNA in blood or urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a taupathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Huntington’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tauopathies are neurodegenerative disorders characterized by tau protein accumulation. Alzheimer’s disease, FTLD-tau, and some atypical Parkinsonian syndromes (PSP, CBD) are tauopathies. questions.text: A patient underwent serum electrophoresis whose image is provided. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient?

Hepatic cirrhosis presents with β-γ bridging due to polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Serum protein electrophoresis is an essential diagnostic tool in evaluating protein abnormalities in nephrotic syndrome, multiple myeloma, and chronic liver diseases.

  • ➤ Serum protein electrophoresis is an essential diagnostic tool in evaluating protein abnormalities in nephrotic syndrome, multiple myeloma, and chronic liver diseases.

questions.text: In a patient receiving recurrent transfusions for thalassemia, the development of fever and chills is observed during this period, without any evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can help reduce the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with cancer. The research revealed the role played by a tumor suppressor gene SMAD4. Which of the following is the predominant role played by this gene in the tumor cells?

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with a four-week history of productive cough, pleuritic chest pain, and low-grade fever. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds over the right lower lung field. A chest X-ray shows a cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the right lower lobe. questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 60fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HbA2 levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mentzer Index (<13 suggests thalassemia, >13 suggests IDA). HbA2 levels are crucial in diagnosing β-thalassemia minor. Iron deficiency anemia responds to iron therapy, whereas thalassemia does not.
  • ➤ Mentzer Index (<13 suggests thalassemia, >13 suggests IDA).

  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia responds to iron therapy, whereas thalassemia does not.

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benzene exposure increases the risk of acute leukemias (ALL and AML). Benzidine and aniline dyes cause bladder cancer. Lung cancer is primarily linked to smoking, asbestos, and radon exposure. Basal cell carcinoma is caused by UV radiation and heavy metals (e.g., arsenic).
  • ➤ Benzene exposure increases the risk of acute leukemias (ALL and AML).
  • ➤ Benzidine and aniline dyes cause bladder cancer.
  • ➤ Lung cancer is primarily linked to smoking, asbestos, and radon exposure.
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is caused by UV radiation and heavy metals (e.g., arsenic).

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome should be suspected in a female with short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, lymphedema, and increased carrying angle (cubitus valgus). A key additional finding is streak gonads , leading to primary ovarian failure and infertility.
  • ➤ short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, lymphedema, and increased carrying angle (cubitus valgus).
  • ➤ streak gonads

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thymoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is strongly associated with thymoma. If a patient presents with PRCA and a mediastinal mass, thymoma should be the first consideration.
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is strongly associated with thymoma.
  • ➤ thymoma should be the first consideration.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with fever, fatigue, and night sweats. He has a history of mitral valve prolapse. On auscultation, a holosystolic murmur is heard at the apex. His echocardiography revealed large, friable and irregular vegetations on heart valves. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infective endocarditis should be suspected in patients with fever, a new murmur, and echocardiographic evidence of large, friable vegetations. Mitral valve prolapse is a known predisposing factor for IE.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kawasaki disease should be suspected in any child with prolonged fever (≥5 days), rash, limb edema, conjunctivitis, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The most dangerous complication is coronary artery aneurysm leading to myocardial infarction, and treatment includes IVIG and aspirin.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. This patient is kept under regular follow-up to diagnose which of the following malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enteric T cell lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with celiac disease, particularly those with persistent symptoms despite a gluten-free diet, are at an increased risk for enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (EATL), a serious and aggressive malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea?

options.label: C

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a painless abdominal mass, abdominal pain, and hematuria. On physical examination, a large, palpable, non-tender abdominal mass is noted. Which of the following is not correct about this condition?

options.text: Nephrogenic rests are a precursor lesion

options.label: B
options.text: Gene affected in this condition is present on short arm of chr11

options.label: C
options.text: Wild type of P53 is associated with poor prognosis

options.label: D
options.text: Histology reveals blastemal, stromal & epithelial components

Ans. C) Wild type of P53 is associated with poor prognosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilms tumor is a common childhood renal malignancy associated with mutations in WT1 and WT2 on chromosome 11p. It has a triphasic histology and can arise from nephrogenic rests. Poor prognosis is associated with P53 mutation and anaplasia, not the wild-type (normal) P53.
